content:
Original:
2 =< size <= 100
45 =< angle <= 2295 
Edited:
2 <= size <= 100
45 <= angle <= 2295

About the sentence:

"Angle is provided in degrees and is dividable by 45."

I think in mathematics "divisible" is more commonly used than "dividable". In fact, I do not remember seeing "dividable" used in any math text I read. Also, the sentence is not very precise, as in fact you mean:

"Angle is provided in degrees and is an odd multiple of 45".

But overall, the puzzle is quite interesting, and could be fun to solve. Good luck.
There is no test case for rotation=225 mod 360, but validator 2 tries it. This would result in complaints if we approved.
I don't like when someone transposes a matrix by 45 degrees. Sad!

I like everything except the difference between test1 and validator1. Since the output of test1 is symmetrical, you can pass test1 if you have made an error in how you did the rotation. Which I did. Validator1 is not symetrical, so you can fail the validator and pass the test which I think is not great. 

I suggest you validate a slightly different square something like:
k # # # #
# - . . #
# # - . #
# # # - #
# # # # k

Sorry, but I don't like it. :(

And those trailing spaces are killing me.


Edit: This puzzle might be a good clash of code.
This can be messy with languages like C++. I like it :)
it cool
having the angle contraints to only show a diamond shape limits your code to possible bugs

Those outputs do not match the given angles. I don't know PHP but I suspect you have a mistake when you simplified the angle.

990° should be a square rather than a diamond.
1395° is congruent to -45°,  but you've rotated it 135° clockwise.
etc.
You're right, will try to fix those.
Thx for the input, I'm not sure I understand. You're suggesting that there should be more tests that rotate the matrix by angles 90, 180, 270? What's the fun in that?

> Sorry, but I don't like it. :(

that's fine, not all puzzles are in my taste too. I quite like problems related to string operations. I'm sure that there are others who like it too. 

> And those trailing spaces are killing me.
Tailing spaces after each character? It would be hard to form a diamond shape without the spaces. I've decided to add those to input for consistency. 

Or do you rather mean tailing spaces after the last character that forms diamond shape? 

There is no consistency in CG quizzes that produce output similar to mine. Although from what I've seen the majority do add spaces in the end when producing the output.

Thx I guess. Would you care to explain what is it that you don't like? This is my first puzzle and I joined CG to learn. 

I titled the puzzle matrix spinner, and in the goal, it states: ...rotate matrix counterclockwise by an angle. I'm not sure if it's the tags that bother you or use of the word matrix. Maybe I should have used "rectangle" instead? 

You're quite a high lvl so I'd really like to know.

Oops... Good point. I missed that. I guess that should be easy to fix.

Validators using the same angle and size while changing the pattern should be quite enough to prevent hard coded solutions.

And as wyrdoe pointed out, the patterns should present the same symetries in both cases.

I've withdrawn my approval until that problem is fixed.

If the tests get an overhaul, I suggest using patterns that would progressively detect likely mistakes like:
- rotation in the wrong direction (first pattern should be completely symetrical)
- different handling of even and odd square size
- possible rouding problems (believe it or not, I solved this puzzle using an actual rotation of the coordinates and ran into a floating point precision problem that would have my code work only up to a certain pattern size :D ). Presenting patterns of the same size (let's say 5 and 6 to check both even and odd dimensions) at first, and a big one (20 or 30) at the end could test that.
- performing a symetry instead of  a rotation (a pattern with an axial symetry could work with such a bug, if the angle is well chosen)
- wrong angle modulo (first tests should present angles withtin the [0,360[ range and only then go beyond 360°)
Thank you, I've updated the statement.

Yep, you've got it right. "Transpose" tag seems totally misleading to me. "String manipulation" would fit right i guess. Also I'd suggest you to use something like "rectangular block of strings" instead of the "matrix" word.

@bobby2: it is hard to explain why we don't like your puzzle.

To begin with, it is not a bad one, and you really are improving it according to our comments (which is why I have removed my refusal).

That being said:
1. This puzzle is really easy to solve.
2. It is very similar to https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/470ee2d6180bd41469770d13396894d8b61 , with the same issue regarding the ridiculously small number of rotations (see my comment there) *and* with this strange restriction of "angle % 90 = 45".

Either you want to have diamond-shape only with smalls angles, and I do believe that this is more suitable for a Clash of code. Or you want this puzzle to be a community puzzle and you should probably allow any angle that is a multiple of 45° and put large ones in the tests/validators.
Understood, I know it's nothing personal :)
The puzzle doesn't make me sad now. :thumbsup:

I refer to the trailing spaces (after the last non-blank character of each line).

These are just annoying, especially since we can't see seem in the example and they are not mentioned in the statement.



Oh, and now Validator 1 is no more equivalent to Test 1. You should change the first '#' in Test 1 by 'o' (or anything but '#' and 'k').

Thx for the response. The output does state: 
Rotated matrix with spaces on both ends.

Maybe there is a better way to phrase this or should I add it to the statement ?
___

Can you please explain what you mean by "Validator 1 is no more equivalent to Test 1" I think its' something @wyrode pointed out as well but I'm not sure what you mean by that? 
I can't think of a reason why input like this:
o # # # #
# - . . #
# # - . #
# # # - #
# # # # #
Would be more equivalent to Test 1 input.

Indeed, the part in the output section seems good enough for the trailing spaces. 


As for Validator 1, people will eventually mess up with the 'k' and put it at some wrong place. With the surrounding being made only of #, such a mistake cannot be detected.

I know that this is a minor point, but we should limit as much as possible situations where a codingamer will pass a test but fail the corresponding validator.


Edit: Another solution would be to put a surrounding of 'k's in Validator 1.
Thank you.
Thx for pointing those out. I've changed the solution and the test cases.
